text:
- I like it when I'm more
concerned than you are Elayna.
That's my preference.
- We had a bit of an incident yesterday.
- I talked to Francois. He's a beauty.
- [Elayna] You boys.
- [Riley] Ah, Mr. And Mr. Whitelum.
(laughing)
- Yep!
- (upbeat instrumental music)

- [Elayna] Here on La
Vagabonde in the Caribbean,

you joined us in the
Turks and Caicos Islands.

As we explored what
the place had to offer.

We were really impressed
with it's natural beauty.
It reminded me a lot of Australia.
- Look at that.
- [Elayna] Oh, Man. What?
- [Riley] It's ridiculous.
I haven't seen anything like that, ever.

- Tony and I are making
a bread this morning.

So, I'm just hear reading
out the ingredients
off the Internet.
- One and a half?
- One and half cups, yeah.
- We'll defy the recipe and just add
'till it gets to a nice consistency.

- So we used Spelt flour,
some pink Himalayan sea salt,
some oats, flax seeds, pumpkin seeds,
honey and that's it, for now.
Pretty simple.
Oh, and the yeast.
I don't know where that went.
- We're going to allow room for expansion.
So, that'll expand and push it all out.
Lay it out in the sun.

- Well, it doesn't get
much better than this.
We can't tell how much wind we have today

because the instrument's
still being out of action.
Riley, how much wind do you think we have?
- Twenty-five knots.

- Riley thinks we have
twenty-five knots and

we've got no swell because
it's coming from here.
(soothing music)

- Some pretty gnarly
weather headed our way.
Well we're in it right now, actually.
(soothing music)
- Alright, ready?
- [Riley] Yeah.
- The weather got so rough,
that we had to turn around.

There's no way we could have
made it to the North Coast.

There was just a bit too much
North in the wind, so ...

We've had to turn around
and we're going back to ...

We're going to anchor in
front of a white sandy beach
for the resort.
So, yes and we'll try...
We need some supplies, actually.

So, I think the ladies
are trying to figure out
a way to get to town.
Is that right?
- There's always tomorrow.

- [Elayna] Yeah, well
hopefully the bread works out.
(laughing)
- I don't think we'll starve.
- [Elayna] No.
- There we go, its magic.
(Elayna laughing)

- I like it when I'm more
concerned than you are Elayna.
That's my preference.
- [Elayna] What did the wind get up to?

- Well, I've only got a
thing where I can look at it,

rather than a daily maximum,
and I saw a thirty-five.

So, I'm tipping we
would have done at least
a few forties in there.
- [Elayna] Whoops, she's done it again.

Turns out, this is not yeast,
we're not sure what it is.
Deja Vu, Tony?
- Yes, indeed.

- [Elayna] Does this remind
you of anything in particular?
Any trip?

- Well, the Pacific crossing,
we had to use a power tool
to cut through it.

- [Elayna] So we now
have a very dense brick.
Sorry to let everyone down.
I'm just going to go check on our anchor.
("Give All" Mimi Gilbert)
- So, we came into a marina a few days ago

to get some diesel, firstly,
and also this is the place
where we're going to be leaving the boat,
because we're actually flying to Barbados

to visit the US embassy so
we can apply for a US Visa.

And hopefully they a
approve it, and we can start

heading North through the
Bahamas and up to Florida
as soon as it's approved, so this is where

we'll be leaving the boat
for, I can't remember
how many days.
I think like four days or something
like that we're in Barbados.

So today, we said goodbye
to Honey and Stelene.
It was actually quite sad.
They were so lovely to have on board,
so easy to have on board ...
So, we love you guys!
Good luck on the rest of your travels.
And we had a bit of an incident yesterday,
so I'll let Tony explain it to you.
Not really good.

[Elayna] Please tell us
what happened yesterday
with your fingers.

- Well, Elayna, I was trying
to be very helpful to you

and the skipper because
some boats have been coming
in very quickly, causing wake.

And the boat was knocking up
against one of the pylons.

So, I found the pylon that
was causing the most trouble.

And I put my hand down the
side to rub on the boat
to see if there'd been any damage.

And, of course, someone
came past, caused more wake,

and squashed my fingers
between the pylon and the boat.
And split this pair pretty badly.
- [Riley] Really badly.

- So we went off to see
Dr. Francois Bourne at

the Mense's clinic for some
short, sharp, shiny surgery.

- [Elayna] Yep, we've been
there a few times now,
haven't we?
You boys.
- Ah, Mr. and Mr. Whitelum.
- [Elayna] Yeah!
(laughing)
Should we show the hospital footage?
- Yeah.
- [Elayna] It's pretty horrific.

- Cue the footage. Look
away if you're squeamish.
- (doctor speaking)
- [Riley] What do you reckon?
- [Riley] That's magic isn't it?
- It is.
Isn't it?

- So, I went to the beach
when all of this was happening

and when I came back,
the first thing I did

was open up the esky to
get a drink out with ice,
and - I'm not kidding - there was, like,

blood inside the esky and
was like, "What the hell?"

First thing I thought
of was, like, a fish,

but I knew the boys didn't
go fishing, and then

Stelene and Honey were
like, there's been a bit

of an accident and the boys
are going to the hospital.
Do not drink that ice. Do not go near it.

- The doctor, apart from
being a good stitch artist
is a great fisherman.
- [Riley] And he gave us a lift home.
- And he gave us a lift back to the boat.
He's an absolute wizard.
Dr. Francois, he's a beauty.

So, we just dropped off Tony
and Joanne at the airport.
It was a pretty emotional goodbye,

because we don't know when
we'll be seeing them again.

Unfortunately, it's just
going to be Riley and I
on the boat, by ourselves again.
(upbeat techno music)
- Just kidding. Just mucking around.

No, it is really, really
good having guests on board.
For me, having Dad and Joanne,
and Honey, and Stelene on board,

I mean, they're some of
our oldest family friends.
That was really was a thrill to give them,
- A taste of what it's like.

It was good to show them
how it is that we live,

and just - yeah - show them
our world for a change.
- But what I'd like to talk about now
is the series of mistakes that I made, and

how difficult it was
leading up to the point

where I said, "Let's meet
in Turks and Caicos."
- On this date.

- On a particular date,
which is always difficult.
Generally speaking, I find you either
leave too early or leave too late.

It's really rare that
you absolutely nail -

Okay, I'm going to definitely
be here at this stage.
Because you gotta predict weather

and all of that sort of
stuff and you'll either

be hanging around whilst
you're wanting to push on

or, like we were, hammering
it last minute and

putting yourself under
pressure to get from -
- We left it very last minute to get here.
- So, if I take you back to St. Martin,

I wanted to go spear-fishing
at Sombrero Island.

And the weather just looked
like - three days out it looked
like the weather was it `just going to be
flat and calm and beautiful, but

it stayed three days
out for about four days.

So I would just wait and
wait and wait and wait.
And in the end I was like, we gotta go.
So we went to Sombrero Island and
we hung out there for a couple of days.

Once again, the weather
changed when we were there.
So it was going to be okay, and

then it looked like it'd be
better if we waited a day
and then we waited a day, and we should
have left the day before.

So, after we did our
thing at Sombrero Island -

now we're getting quite
under the pump time-wise.

And we had to drop Stefan off
in the Dominican Republic,
which is another thing.

I should have said, "Look, the
way things are panning out,

we're just not going
to be able to do that."
- Yeah.
- But we did it anyway, so there were some
really sleepless nights on the way there.
We arrived; I was completely exhausted.

We got there, there was a check
checking in, checking out.

- We did get to go on that
wicked last-minute bike ride.

- Yep, but which also
put us under the pump.
- Yeah, it did. It did.
- And we said goodbye to Stefan.
So then, the next day, we're leaving again

and it wasn't the weather's
fault, it was my fault.

We had to go up and across,
rather than straight there,

which I should have taken into
consideration, and I didn't.

And that's when I fell
asleep near the reef.
Then we went in, dodged all the reef,

which was pretty good, but the
depth sounder wasn't spot on,
which we figured out too late.
- And also the channel marker.
- The channel markers had been blown away,

and I made the mistake of
deviating out of the channel

while letting us get
blown across the channel
out of the channel.
We were probably trying to go too slow.
- For good reason, bloody hell!
None of that looks very safe.

- [Riley] Yeah, we drifted
out of the channel.
It wasn't a big deal in the end,

because we just got
pushed up onto some sand,
but we did run aground.

- [Elayna] Damaged the
rudder a little bit.
- And then fell out of the hatch.

And then Dad and Joanne and
Honey and Stelene arrived

the next day, just
after I got stitches in.
That's just an example of what it took
to get from Sombrero Island to the Caicos
to meet up with some people.

And I think that's a pretty
good lesson for everyone
to learn from my mistakes is that

I'm always saying that
putting yourself under
time pressure is the drama.

And I made - I must have made
six or ten - balls out, sir.
That was a very detailed case study
on how not to run a boat.

- Everyone's gone now, obviously,
so Riley and I just like,

well Riley mostly, today, just
cleaned the house spotless,

but we still have to empty
the fridges and stuff,

because we are flying to
Barbados to apply for a US Visa.
So, that's there requirement.
They're not asking a lot, are they?

We've got to fly all the
way there for a few days,
but it'll be fun.
- It's nearly as difficult as
getting into Australia, I'm told.
- Yeah.

- [Elayna] So, this is my
oldest, most favourite suitcase

and we retrieved it
from the forward cabin,

and it was covered in mould
and all the zips are locked.
- Even though it's really, really
clean and dry down there, but it's

the only place that we
could fit it, so ...

- [Elayna] There must have
been a tiny bit of water
and then it just got ahold of it.
So Riley is fixing my stuck zip.
Yes!
- No.
- [Elayna] No?
- Not yet.
Yes! Got it.
- [Elayna] Thank you!
- No worries.

- [Elayna] The boat in
front of us are leaving.
- [Male Boater] Hey, Riley!
- Hey guys.
- [Female Boater] Safe travels!
- Well done.
- [Male Boater] Thank you.

- [Elayna] So, we're not
going to be far behind
the boat that just left.
We're just waiting for high tide,
and we're going to slip the lines and
head out to a mooring bull for the night.
It's going to be pretty rough out there

on the mooring bull, but
I think we'll be alright.

And then, bright and
early tomorrow morning
we're leaving for a day sail,
hopefully we'll get there in a day,
to our first stop in the Bahamas.
- It's 100 miles, I'm pretty sure it is.
I'll have to double check that,
but I think it's 100 miles, but

we hope to do that from
really early in the morning
and get there sort of mid-afternoon.

- That'd be nice, and with
the winds that we have,
we should be flying.
- [Elayna] What are we up to this morning?

- I've just donned - we
got a climbing harness

when I was in France,
because they're way cheaper
than the stuff you buy at West Marine
and all your marine stores.
I'm just going to up the mast and
have a look at all the rigging, and
I'm going to shorten the halyard
for the main sail by 30 centimetres,
because Matthew said, and obviously,

all of the wear is going to be
on all of your revving points

so you cut off 30 centimetres
and it shortens everything,

so that all the wear
is in different places.

It's just been about
time that we did that.
- [Elayna] Alright, ready to go up?
- [Riley] Yep.
Alright, hold there.
(Soothing music)
Yep!
- Last time my neck hurt this bad
was when we went rock climbing
in France with Lee and his girlfriend.

I forgot how much it hurts
looking up like this.
(soothing music)
- [Elayna] We hope you like that one.
Join us next time at Acklins Island,
our first stop in the Bahamas.

We're really pumped to
have finally made it here.

- I was just looking
at all the stuff here,
like the countdown and all of that.
Oh my God, it's still going.
- [Tony] Just stop the tape.

(water lapping against
the side of the boat)
